text: (bright techno music)

- Hi, I'm Werner Vogels, Chief
Technology Officer of Amazon.
Today, I'm excited to talk to you
about a very cool new launch at AWS.

When I first started working
with distributed systems,
the tools we had as developers were crude
compared to the modern tools of today.
But as frameworks have made certain
aspects of development easier,
and computer code has gone on to have
an impact on almost every industry.
One thing hasn't changed, software bugs.

Bugs are just inevitable,
when you're writing code.
We've all seen how the cloud

has turbocharged the
speed at which developers
are able to build and deploy new features.
Today, the volume of code to inspect

has increased from
thousands of lines of code
to literally millions of lines.

A lot of effort is spent in
finding and eliminating bugs
in this large code base.

It often takes an event,
such as a bug bash,

to set aside time and focus on
addressing these code issues
that build up over time.
Sure, fixing bugs is critical.
But being a developer is about creating,

it's about innovating,
and it's about building.
That's why today I'm happy to announce
AWS BugBust.
The world's largest bug bashing challenge.
It is dedicated to improving code quality
using the power of machine learning

with a mission to bust 1
million bugs worldwide,

all while helping AWS
customers decrease costs.
Available in the AWS Console,
organizations can run their own,
private, virtual bug bashing events,
securely capturing how many bugs are fixed
and how much money is saved over time.
In just a few clicks, DevOps leaders
can quickly set up a bug busting event,

scan their code using Amazon
CodeGuru and start competing.
Once a BugBust event is set up,

a dashboard will show
your team's available bugs

so they can start busting
to score points and win.
Once a BugBust event is complete,

developers can add their points
to the global leaderboard,
where they will compete with developers
from around the world
to become the ultimate AWS BugBuster.

The more events you run,
the more points, rewards,

and prizes developers
will win for busting bugs.
The top 10 BugBusters on the leaderboard
will win a trip to AWS re:Invent,

where they will be celebrated
for their achievements

and take part in the
first live AWS BugBust.
BugBust changes the game, quite literally,
all while helping companies save money
by making their code more efficient.
I'm excited to see how technologies,

like Automated Reasoning
and Machine Learning,
are helping developers to be even better
by powering tools like Amazon CodeGuru.

AWS BugBust will help
customers revolutionize

one of the most tedious
steps in code development,
and best of all, have fun doing it!
Now, go out,
go bust some bugs,
and go build!
(music crescendos)
